pull.title: Restore overview page (put transactions back within frame)
pull.body:
Fix some layout weirdness introduced in #1314.
Also, change "(out of sync)" to only red, instead of red and bold, which a bit more subtle for a warning.

repo.name: bitcoin
repo.description: Laanwj's Bitcoin Core fork - see README.md on "readme" branch

events.body: Sorry to have introduced that one ...

Ok, removed the font tag completely.

I've also made it so that the (out of sync) label appears directly after Wallet and Recent transactions, and is not aligned to the middle.
I can't verify that change by just looking at the diff, which hits me hard, but ACK to the intention :D.

Why not simply try it out?

```
$ git add remote wumpus https://github.com/laanwj/bitcoin.git
$ git fetch wumpus
$ git checkout wumpus/2012_05_overviewpage_restore
$ (build...)
```

I guess you will LOL, when I tell you how I test commits. Merged ones to master go into Bitcoin, I fetch them via git fetch upstream, rebase and then open a file-compare-tool and add every changed line into my test-build and compile it. Now next problem was I did never use other remotes, just the bitcoin one, but I will try your commands tomorrow :), it's late.

Hehe, that does sounds quite inefficient indeed.

The simplest way to do it is to `git clone https://github.com/laanwj/bitcoin.git` into a new directory then check out the branch `git checkout 2012_05_overviewpage_restore`. Then build from there.

Remotes are essentially the same, but allow for tracking multiple remote repositories from one local git repository. This can be useful, for example, when you want to create a local branch from the remote branch and continue working on it. Or to do diffs between a branch of your own and the remote one. (However, it also means that you have to first commit your current work to a branch, or stash, before you can check out the other remote branch)

Learning to use git effectively can be a bit of a challenge in the beginning, but it does pay off.

Thanks for this Git lesson :). I'm already advancing, my first pulls were done via merges and I created so much mess, Con (developer of CGMINER) still hates me for them I guess ^^.

Would a `git clone https://github.com/laanwj/bitcoin.git bitcoin_wumpus` work, so that I can use bitcoin_wumpus as directory? Do I need to fork your repo via the Github website first? Btw. which tag are you using to display the commands, seems its not the HTML-pre.

Yes, that's would work well. You don't have to do anything on the github website. You can make as many local clones and forks as you want, that's the advantage of a distributed VCS.

I use `` (backticks) for the commands.

I need your help GIT-wise, sorry to OT this discussion :).
I did:

`git clone git://github.com/laanwj/bitcoin.git -b master bitcoin_wumpus`
`cd bitcoin_wumpus`
`git remote add upstream git://github.com/laanwj/bitcoin.git -m master`
`git fetch upstream -p`
`git checkout 2012_05_overviewpage`

Which leads me to a `error: pathspec '2012_05_overviewpage' did not match any file(s) known to git`. I tried the https version, which led me to the same error. This steps were the same I did some time ago for the official bitcoin Git. Any ideas?

git checkout upstream/2012_05_overviewpage

edit: `git branch -a` to get a list of all branches
Ahhh okay currently I only checkout local branches and this is a remote one ...
I guess I should have added `_restore`, now it worked :). Checked out the changes and they work and look good, so ACK!

events.message:
Restore overviewpage (put transactions back within frame)

- Also, change "(out of sync)" to only red, instead of red and bold, which a bit more subtle
- Move label stylesheets to xml

events.body: Moved the color:red stylesheets to the XML file.
